question: A 25-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department of a rural hospital after being struck on the right side of his head by a blunt instrument during a home invasion. His condition has deteriorated rapidly and he now has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 6 and his right pupil is fixed and dilated. He is intubated. The regional neurosurgical centre is three hours travel away. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial plan of management?
options: Urgent transfer to the regional neurosurgery unit

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic after his blood pressure was found to be 160/100 mmHg at a routine check at his local pharmacy. He has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not take any regular medications other than metformin, which he finds difficult to remember to take regularly. He is an active smoker. On examination, he appears well. His pulse rate is 78/min, blood pressure 162/96 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.7°C. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are unremarkable. Investigations reveal: Urine dipstick: negative for red blood cells, positive for protein Urine albumin-creatinine ratio: 35 mg/mmol (0-3.5) HbA1c: 8.0% (4.0-5.6) Which one of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient's hypertension?

A 65-year-old woman is electively admitted to start a course of chemotherapy for her acute myeloid leukaemia. She is on no medications at home and is started on enoxaparin at admission. Her full blood count (FBC) at admission shows mild anaemia and normal platelets, with a slightly elevated white cell count. On day 10 of her chemotherapy cycle, her FBC shows Haemoglobin 69 g/L (125 - 160), platelets 27x10^9/L (150 - 450) and neutrophils 0.3x10^9/L (1.8 – 7.5). She is haemodynamically stable and has had a Group and Hold in the last 72 hours. After reviewing these blood results, which one of the following is the next most appropriate step in management?
options: Examine the patient and if they are fine, do nothing
Request urgent blood products to be sent to the ward
Transfuse one unit RBCs and cease enoxaparin

question: A 35-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a one-week history of double vision. Three days ago, he noticed slurring of his speech and difficulty swallowing. Yesterday, he developed impaired balance. He reports an episode of severe diarrhoea two weeks ago but is otherwise in good health. He does not smoke and drinks alcohol socially. He takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 80/min, blood pressure 116/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. Neurological examination reveals limitation of eye movement laterally and upwards, and bilateral ptosis. His pupils are equal and reactive. His speech is slurred, and he has sluggish palate movements. Muscle power is normal, but deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper and lower limbs. Heel-to-shin testing is abnormal, and tandem gait is severely impaired. Investigations reveal a normal complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel. Urine toxicology screens are negative. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with her daughter reporting worsening control of her Parkinson disease symptoms over three months. She experiences increasing periods where her medications seem ineffective, with severe tremor and difficulty walking, alternating with periods of good symptom control. These 'off' periods are becoming more frequent and prolonged, particularly before her next medication dose is due. She has a history of Parkinson disease diagnosed eight years ago with associated cognitive impairment, hypertension, dyslipidaemia and type 2 diabetes. Her medications include levodopa-carbidopa 100/25mg four times daily, metformin, rosuvastatin, amlodipine, and paracetamol. On examination, she appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She displays a resting tremor, cogwheel rigidity, and bradykinesia, isolated to the right side, worse in the upper limb. She is oriented to time, place, and person with intact comprehension. Her gait is slow and shuffling with reduced arm swing. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Switch to levodopa-carbidopa controlled release preparation
Reduce levodopa-carbidopa dose and give six times daily
Increase levodopa-carbidopa dose and give four times daily
Refer for percutaneous pump for levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel

question: An 18-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department of a rural hospital after falling three metres head-first onto concrete at a building site. He was not wearing a helmet. Initially he was able to walk, but became confused 30 minutes after the fall, prompting his colleagues to drive him to hospital. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. An A to E assessment has been carried out and he has been successfully intubated by a colleague. On further examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 40/min, blood pressure 160/90 mmHg, respiratory rate 14/min, SpO2 100% (intubated), and temperature 36.8°C. He responds to pain with withdrawal, eye opening and incoherent sounds. There is a haematoma over the right temple. His right pupil is dilated with absent light reflexes, while the left pupil is normal size with normal light reflexes. The nearest neurosurgical centre is 90 minutes away by road. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 39-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a three-day history of urinary frequency and burning on micturition. This is the third episode she has had in the last three months. She has no other symptoms and is otherwise in good health. Her medical history includes a laparoscopy for endometriosis six months ago. She does not take any regular medications. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Abdominal examination is unremarkable with no tenderness or masses. Urine is sent for analysis and in the interim a CT is performed (Image). Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for the abnormal CT findings?
options: Recurrent E. coli urinary tract infection

question: A four-year-old boy presents to the Emergency Department via ambulance with sudden onset hoarse voice and urticarial rash immediately following a bee sting. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 130/min and blood pressure 85/50 mmHg. Intravenous access has been obtained. Which one of the following blood tests is most likely to support the diagnosis of anaphylaxis if performed within two hours of symptom onset?
options: Complement C3a, C4a and C5a levels

question: A 62-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic with sudden onset right arm pain after weightlifting at the gym. While performing an upper body exercise, he felt a sharp pain and audible 'pop' in his right arm. He has noticed a visible lump in his upper arm since the injury. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. He is an ex-professional basketball player. On examination, he appears well with vital signs within normal limits. There is an obvious bulge in the right upper arm (Image). The area is tender to palpation. He has full range of movement at the shoulder and elbow joints. Distal neurovascular examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate method to confirm the diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a four-day history of vague abdominal discomfort and nausea. Her medical history is not immediately available. A plain abdominal X-ray is ordered as part of the assessment. (Image) Which one of the following is the most relevant finding on the X-ray?

An 81-year-old woman with known diabetes and chronic kidney disease is admitted for a hypertensive crisis. On the third day of her hospital stay, though her blood pressure is well controlled, she complains of right knee pain. There is no history of any trauma and she is on metformin, frusemide and perindopril. On examination, her weight is 74 kg, height 164 cm, her blood pressure is 128/80 mmHg, pulse 90/min and temperature 37.2°C. On examination, her right knee shows tenderness, erythema, and swelling, but has full range of motion. Aspiration of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped crystals, and no features of septic joint. Her serum creatinine is 212 umol/L (53 - 97), urea 12.5 mmol/L (2.1 - 8.5), serum uric acid 0.51 mmol/L (<0.36 mmol/L) and random blood sugar 12.1 mmol/L (3.2 - 5.5). Which one of the following is the most appropriate management?

A 55-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with several hours of bleeding per rectum. He reports suddenly passing a large volume of dark-red blood (estimated as several large cups) with some clots. He has not had any recent gastrointestinal symptoms. His medical history includes insertion of a coronary artery stent five years ago, for which he takes aspirin. Eight years ago, he had a duodenal ulcer related to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug use, which was treated with esomeprazole. He does not take any other regular medications. On examination, he appears well. His pulse rate is 100/min, blood pressure 125/95 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO₂ 98% on room air, and temperature 37.2°C. Cardiovascular examination is unremarkable, apart from a soft ejection systolic murmur. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness or masses. Digital rectal examination shows the presence of red-brown blood. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of the rectal bleeding?

A 30-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of right calf pain and swelling. She is 37 weeks pregnant with her second child. Her first pregnancy was uncomplicated. She has noticed increasing breathlessness over the past month. She has no significant medical history and takes only pregnancy vitamins. On examination, she appears well. Her pulse rate is 85/min, blood pressure 118/75 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO₂ 98% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. Her right calf is swollen, tender and erythematous compared to the left. Chest examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A 35-year-old woman who is 32 weeks pregnant with twins receives treatment for iron deficiency anaemia. At the beginning of her pregnancy, her ferritin level was 2 µg/L without anaemia. She was started on oral iron supplementation. One week ago, her iron studies showed a ferritin level of 15 µg/L. She reports constipation from the iron supplements and would like to consider an iron infusion. She also has asthma and throughout this pregnancy has developed gestational diabetes and pre-eclampsia. Which one of the following factors would increase the patient's risk of an adverse reaction to the iron infusion?

A 52-year-old woman presents to her GP with fatigue and tingling in her hands and feet for the last several months. These symptoms have progressively worsened with time. The patient reports no medical history but did undergo gastric bypass surgery two years ago for weight loss management. She has never smoked, drinks two standard drinks per week, and eats a vegetarian diet. Which one of the following is most likely to be revealed by the blood tests or blood smear for this patient?

A six-month-old boy presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of breathlessness and bluish discolouration of the skin. He has a known history of Tetralogy of Fallot and is awaiting corrective surgery. He has no other significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears distressed with marked cyanosis. His pulse rate is 160/min, respiratory rate 60/min, SpO2 70% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. Cardiovascular examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border. The emergency physician recognises this as a hypercyanotic spell and immediately places the infant in a knee-to-chest position. Which one of the following best explains the physiological basis for using the knee-to-chest position in this situation?
options: Increased venous return to the heart

question: An otherwise well 47-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with a three week history of intermittent pain and swelling under the right side of his jaw. This is not always noticeable and seems to vary in size, particularly after a meal. On examination there is a soft, non-tender 3 cm swelling immediately under right mandible and some 5 cm anterior to the angle of the jaw. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?

A 69-year-old woman presents with a six month history of early satiety. She has no other symptoms and is otherwise well. Physical examination is unremarkable and a CT scan is performed (Image). Which of the following structures are in their incorrect anatomical place?

A 28-year-old woman presents to the antenatal clinic at 32 weeks gestation. This is her first pregnancy and she has no significant medical history. She does not take any regular medications. She is a non-smoker and works as an accountant. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Her symphysis-fundal height measures 28 cm. A growth scan two weeks ago showed the estimated fetal weight on the 7th centile. Which one of the following is the most accurate method of diagnosing intrauterine growth restriction?
options: Serial measurements of fetal abdominal circumference
Serial measurements of amniotic fluid index
Serial measurements of estimated fetal weight

question: A newborn girl is examined shortly after birth. The pregnancy was complicated by intrauterine growth restriction noted on ultrasound scans. She was delivered at 38 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 1.9 kg. She has no significant family history and her parent's antenatal screening was declined. On examination, she appears unwell with a pulse rate of 150/min, blood pressure 65/40 mmHg, respiratory rate 65/min, SpO2 89% on room air, and temperature 36.5°C. She has a small jaw, low-set ears, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and prominent calcanei (rocker-bottom feet). A loud systolic murmur is heard on cardiac examination. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with haematemesis following a prolonged bout of intense retching and vomiting. He has a history of alcohol misuse but no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. He denies any previous episodes of chest or abdominal pain. His stool appearance and consistency are normal and unchanged. On examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 110/min, blood pressure 102/68 mmHg, respiratory rate 24/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 37.0°C. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Digital rectal examination reveals brown stool. His vomit appears to contain fresh bright red blood. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A three-day-old boy undergoes routine newborn bloodspot screening. He appears well and is feeding normally. He has no significant medical history and his mother had an uncomplicated pregnancy. The screening result shows an immunoreactive trypsinogen level above the 99th percentile. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 70-year-old man is admitted to the General Medicine Unit due to functional decline complicated by COVID-19 infection (confirmed by PCR). He has a 2-day history of shortness of breath, dry cough, general malaise, and loss of appetite. His history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, and chronic back pain from L4/5 disc herniation. He takes perindopril and panadeine forte regularly. On examination, he is alert and oriented to person, time, and place. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, respiratory rate 20/min, pulse 89/min, SpO2 95% on room air, and temperature 37.9°C. His chest is clear. His laboratory investigations show: Hb: 130 (135-175) g/L, WCC: 21.1 (4.0-11.0 x10*9/L), PLT: 120 (150-400 x10*9/L), Cr: 68 (60-110 mol/L). Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A 56-year-old man is retrieved from the scene of a motor vehicle crash, in which he sustained a head injury. He is unconscious and endotracheal intubation is performed. A CT scan of his head is performed and shows intracranial haemorrhage. He is on warfarin for a prosthetic mitral valve. His INR is 2.5. In addition to giving vitamin K, which one of the following is the most appropriate management of his coagulation status?
options: Prothrombin complex concentrate and fresh frozen plasma

question: A 25-year-old man is brought into the Emergency Department of a rural hospital after being struck on the right side of his head by a blunt instrument during a home invasion. His condition has deteriorated rapidly and he now has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 6 and his right pupil is fixed and dilated. He is intubated. The regional neurosurgical centre is three hours travel away. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial plan of management?
options: Urgent transfer to the regional neurosurgery unit

A CT scan of his head is performed and shows intracranial haemorrhage. He is on warfarin for a prosthetic mitral valve. His INR is 2.5. In addition to giving vitamin K, which one of the following is the most appropriate management of his coagulation status?
options: Prothrombin complex concentrate and fresh frozen plasma

question: A 32-year-old G1P0 woman comes for a routine prenatal visit at 28 weeks gestation. This has been her first pregnancy. She has had regular antenatal care and tests performed at her first antenatal visit were unremarkable. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She does not have any significant medical history and currently takes only multivitamins. In her family history her father has hypertension. Her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her blood group is B+ve. Laboratory reports show a haematocrit of 37%. Which of the following options is most appropriate test to perform in this patient? Choose the single best answer.

A 21-year-old male presents acutely agitated with suspected drug-induced psychosis. He is given IM haloperidol and shortly after he complains of visual disturbances. On examination, there is fixed upward deviation of the eyes bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most appropriate management? Choose the single best answer.

A 25-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a six-month history of intense fear and anxiety in social situations. She reports avoiding work meetings, social gatherings, and even grocery shopping due to fear of embarrassment or negative judgment from others. She has no significant medical history and does not take any regular medications. On examination, she appears anxious with a pulse rate of 100/min, blood pressure 130/85 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, SpO2 99% on room air, and temperature 36.7°C. Further assessment reveals that her symptoms are significantly impacting her daily functioning and quality of life. Which one of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient? Choose the single best answer.

A 35-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of acute onset left lower quadrant abdominal pain. She denies fever, nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. She has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Her abdomen is soft with localized tenderness in the left lower quadrant, but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory investigations reveal a white blood cell count of 8.5 x 10^9/L (4.0–11.0). A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is performed. The radiologist reports a 2 cm lesion adjacent to the descending colon in the left lower quadrant. The lesion demonstrates a central dot of high attenuation surrounded by a ring of fat density. There is mild surrounding fat stranding, but no free fluid or pneumoperitoneum. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Choose the single best answer.

A 72-year-old woman is undergoing elective total hip replacement under general anaesthesia. Two hours into the procedure, her core temperature is 35.4°C. She has a medical history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. Her regular medications are amlodipine and paracetamol. On examination, her pulse rate is 88/min, blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 12/min controlled, SpO2 98% on mechanical ventilation, and temperature 35.4°C. The ambient theatre temperature is 20°C. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A newly qualified medical practitioner is preparing to start their first position at a public hospital in Australia. They are reviewing their professional obligations and registration requirements. Which one of the following best describes the requirements for professional indemnity insurance in Australia?
options: Voluntary protection recommended by medical boards
Optional coverage determined by employer preference

question: A 30-year-old woman presents with a pruritic, erythematous eruption across her abdomen. She is 30 weeks pregnant with twins. This is her first pregnancy. She denies any previous medical history, including skin disease. On examination there is a polymorphous erythematous papulosquamous eruption across her abdomen, involving striae gravidarum with sparing of the periumbilical area. No other areas of the body are affected. This clinical picture is consistent with polymorphic eruption of pregnancy, also known as pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy (PUPPP). Histology was nonspecific and direct immunofluorescence studies were negative, which is consistent with the diagnosis of PUPPP. Which statement regarding polymorphic eruption of pregnancy is correct?
options: It is associated with multiple gestation pregnancies
It is associated with autoimmune disease
It is more common with a female foetus
It commonly lasts until 6 months postpartum

question: A previously well 52-year-old man presents with a five-day history of lower abdominal pain. The pain was initially intermittent and has now become constant. He has no other symptoms apart from some intermittent nausea. On examination, the patient's blood pressure is 115/90 mmHg, pulse 100/min and temperature 37.8°C. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the right iliac fossa and no other abnormalities. A CT scan is performed and shown below (image): Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial plan of management?

A 30-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic with a three-month history of progressive tremor, slowed movements, and yellowing of his skin. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. On examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 82/min, blood pressure 125/75 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. He has generalised bradykinesia, rigidity in his limbs, and a resting tremor. There is scleral icterus and mild hepatomegaly with right upper quadrant tenderness. Investigations reveal: Total bilirubin: 34 mol/L (2-20) Aspartate aminotransferase: 86 U/L (5-37) Alanine aminotransferase: 99 U/L (5-42) Prothrombin time: 12 seconds (11-13.5) Viral hepatitis serology: negative. Which one of the following laboratory patterns would be most characteristic of this condition?
options: Low serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper concentrations
Low serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper concentrations
Elevated serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper concentrations
Elevated serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper concentrations
Normal serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper concentrations

question: A 32-year-old man presents with a six-month history of what he describes as ‘brittle nails.’ These have become more troublesome and interfere with his job as a plumber. He has a medical history of type 1 diabetes. His medications include insulin. He is an active smoker with a 25 pack-year history. On examination, his fingernails are as shown (image). The rest of the physical examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?

A previously well 25-year-old woman attends the emergency department two hours after the sudden onset of pain in the right lower abdomen. This is associated with nausea, vomiting and faintness. Her last menstrual period ended 5 weeks ago, and she normally has regular 26 day cycles. She is afebrile. Her blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg and the pulse rate is 120/min. She is tender is the right lower abdomen with guarding, rigidity and rebound tenderness. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 73-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with 12 months of deteriorating vision. She has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with glimepiride and hypertension managed with ramipril. Her best corrected visual acuity is 6/48 in the right eye and 6/36 in the left eye. Fundoscopy shows the presence of yellow deposits under the retina (image). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old man is attending an outpatient appointment for drainage of his ascites which has been refractory to diuretic use. His medical history includes cirrhosis secondary to chronic alcohol abuse diagnosed five years ago, though he has reportedly been abstinent for the past three months. Since diagnosis, he has been admitted on multiple occasions for symptomatic ascites and encephalopathy in the setting of infections, as well as one incident of variceal bleeding two years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, furosemide and spironolactone. On examination, he is alert and has icteric sclera. His blood pressure is 105/68 mmHg, pulse 96/min, temperature 37.4°C and SpO2 96% on room air. His JVP is elevated at 5 cm and there are bilateral basal crackles heard on pulmonary auscultation. His abdomen is distended, with shifting dullness and a positive fluid thrill. Bilateral peripheral oedema is noted. His most recent and relevant investigations include: AST of 130 U/L (10-40 U/L), ALT of 60 U/L (7-56 U/L), Bilirubin: 42umol/L (3-20), INR: 1.5 (<1.1), Albumin 30g/L (>30). An abdominal CT scan confirms cirrhosis with signs of portal hypertension and large oesophageal varices. His eligibility to undergo a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is discussed. Which one of the following would be the strongest indication for this procedure?
options: The previous episodes of variceal bleeding
Signs of decompensated congestive heart failure

question: A 72-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a two-month history of progressively worsening headache. The pain is not better or worse at any time of the day, and at its worst is described as 8/10 in severity. She also reports fatigue, neck and shoulder stiffness and pain, as well as lateral hip pain that she attributes to her history of hip osteoarthritis. She has noticed her right eye vision has been deteriorating recently and thinks she may need new prescription glasses. She denies any previous history of headaches. Her medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis. Her medications include perindopril and hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms. On examination, she appears uncomfortable. Her pulse rate is 87/min, blood pressure 130/82 mmHg, respiratory rate 13/min, SpO2 99% on room air, and temperature 37.7°C. Her temporal arteries are tender to palpation bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man is admitted to ICU following a myocardial infarction. He presents with profound hypotension secondary to low cardiac output, requiring inotropic and vasopressor support. His medical history includes hypertension (previously managed with amlodipine) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (previously managed with metformin). Both medications have been discontinued in ICU. On examination, the patient is anxious and clammy. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and his temperature is 36.8°C. He weighs 70 kg. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the lung bases and the heart sounds are dual with no added sounds. Lower limb examination reveals bilateral pitting oedema. He has no rash. Over the next 48 hours, his serum creatinine rises from 106 μmol/L to 310 μmol/L. His urine output is 20mL/hr. Urine dipstick demonstrates glycosuria. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 76-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a one-month history of a rapidly expanding growth over her left upper gum margin. She has also noted fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss during this one-month period. She has a medical history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia. Her regular medications, which she has been on for four years, are lercanidipine and rosuvastatin. On examination, she appears unwell. Her pulse rate is 85/min, blood pressure 115/65 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 97% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a firm, purple-coloured mass on the left upper gum margin (image). Investigations reveal: Haemoglobin: 85 g/L (115-165), White cell count: 3 x 10⁹/L (4-11), Platelets: 57 x 10⁹/L (150-400), Neutrophils: 0.4 x 10⁹/L (2-7.5), Creatinine: 156 μmol/L (60-110), eGFR: 30 mL/min/1.73m², Lactate dehydrogenase: 560 U/L (120-250), Peripheral blood smear also reveals a high number of blast cells present: 2 x 10⁹/L (<1), 66%. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the image shown?

A previously well 68-year-old man presents with two months of back pain and bilateral lower leg weakness. A detailed history does not provide any other information apart from a loss of libido over the last few years. On examination, there is palpable tenderness over the spinous process in the lumbar region. Strength is 4/5 bilaterally and neurological examination is otherwise unremarkable. It is noted that the man has enlarged breast tissue. There are no visual field defects. Initial laboratory tests including a complete blood examination, electrolytes, urea, creatinine and calcium reveal no abnormalities. A lumbar spine X ray is performed (Image). Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his current problem?

A 24-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology clinic with a 2 year history of chronic pelvic pain. The pain is dull and constant, worse with movement. She takes no regular medications. She doesn't feel the pain relates to regular menses. Menses are usually regular and light. She is on the combined oral contraceptive pill. She hasn't had a cervical screening test as she is under 25 years of age and no abnormal bleeding. She has had chlamydia infections twice previously treated with oral antibiotics. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. The abdomen is soft with mild tenderness on deep palpation of the lower abdomen. There is no guarding or rebound or any masses felt. There is no cervical motion tenderness present on vaginal examination. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. She undergoes diagnostic laparoscopy which reveals adhesions between the anterior surface of the liver and the anterior abdominal wall. There are filmy adhesions between the Fallopian tubes and the side wall and ovaries. Peritoneum otherwise appears normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 86-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with vague, generalised abdominal pain. This pain has been present for several months and is not getting better, but it does get worse at times and does not radiate. She denies vomiting, bowel changes, or urine changes. On examination, her vital signs are normal and her abdomen is soft. A recent set of investigations have been completed and were unremarkable. Her case records show she has presented nearly every month for the past year for either similar abdominal pain or chest pain, with no diagnosis being given after full investigation. Her husband of 50 years died three years ago and she has no family support in Australia. The patient says she is very sad and does not want to live. She has a poor appetite and has stopped eating. She has no energy and finds it very hard to sleep, which has got worse recently and she struggles to care for herself as she has no motivation. Her sisters both live in Greece and she has been unable to travel there for two years due to travel restrictions. She has a medical history of hypertension and bipolar affective disorder. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An eight-year-old boy presents to the General Practice clinic with a three-day history of sore throat and fever. His parent describes a rough-feeling rash that started on his trunk and gradually spread to his arms and legs. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears unwell. His pulse rate is 110/min, blood pressure 100/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 22/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 38.0°C. He has generalised lymphadenopathy. Examination of his oral mucosa reveals an erythematous tongue. There is an erythematous rash that feels fine and rough across his trunk, with lines also present in his armpits and elbow creases. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of nausea, vomiting, with the vomitus containing small amounts of fresh blood. The vomiting began after a night of heavy alcohol consumption. He typically drinks about 20 g of alcohol daily but had been on a binge the evening prior to presentation. He has a two-week history of post-prandial epigastric pain for which he recently started taking esomeprazole. He has no other significant medical history and takes no other regular medications. On examination, he appears mildly dehydrated. His pulse rate is 92/min, blood pressure 128/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.7°C. Abdominal examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman of Greek ancestry presents to her General Practice clinic with fatigue and numbness in her feet over the past three months. She has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. Her medications include metformin, perindopril, digoxin, amiodarone, and rivaroxaban. She has a 20 pack-year smoking history and consumes four glasses of wine per evening on weekends. On examination, she appears well. Her pulse rate is 62/min, blood pressure 138/85 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. Her BMI is 30 kg/m². She has reduced sensation to light touch in a stocking distribution. ECG demonstrates atrial fibrillation. Blood tests reveal: Haemoglobin 98 g/L (115-155), Mean cell volume 100 fL (80-98), Mean cell haemoglobin concentration 320 g/L (310-350), Liver function tests normal, Electrolytes, urea, creatinine normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her anaemia?

A 27-year-old woman presents to her General Practitioner with a three-week history of a lump in her right breast. She has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination the lump is firm, well circumscribed and mobile. There are no other abnormalities in either breast or axillae. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Reassurance and review in one month

question: A 33-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden-onset right-sided pleuritic chest pain and severe shortness of breath following an episode of coughing. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears distressed and is using accessory muscles to breathe. His pulse rate is 112/min, blood pressure 105/65 mmHg, respiratory rate 28/min, SpO2 88% on room air, and temperature 37.0°C. Cardiorespiratory examination reveals increased resonance over the right side of his chest and diminished breath sounds. A mid-systolic click is heard, accompanied by a late systolic murmur that is louder with the handgrip manoeuvre. A chest X-ray confirms a large right-sided pneumothorax (image). The patient is given appropriate analgesia and supplemental oxygen. Needle thoracocentesis has been attempted but was unsuccessful in improving the patient’s symptoms or oxygen saturation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Admission for observation with high-flow oxygen therapy

question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with multiple injuries following a motor vehicle accident. She is a well-known social media influencer. She has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, she appears stable with vital signs within normal limits. She has multiple superficial lacerations to her face and arms. While providing care, you overhear several staff members discussing posting about the incident on social media. One staff member suggests that since no patient identifying information would be included, it would be acceptable to share details about the case. Which one of the following is the most appropriate response to the staff members?
options: Posting is acceptable if images are not included
Posting is acceptable if no names are mentioned
Posting is acceptable if the patient consents
Posting is never acceptable in this situation

question: A 56-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a three-week history of progressive skin discolouration and swelling of her right breast. There has been warmth and tenderness but no discharge. She does not report any fevers, chills, nausea, or vomiting. A week ago, she was diagnosed with mastitis, for which she was prescribed a seven-day course of dicloxacillin. Despite adherence to the medical regimen, her symptoms have worsened. She has no significant medical history and does not take any regular medications. She has two children, menarche was at 13, menopause at 52. Her last mammogram was two years ago and did not show any suspicious lesions. On examination, she appears well. Her blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, pulse 75/min, temperature 37°C, respiratory rate 12/min and SpO2 100% on room air. Gross examination of the breast is shown (image). There are palpable lymph nodes in her right axilla that are firm and fixed. Which one of the following is most likely to diagnose the underlying condition?
options: Fine-needle aspiration of the axillary nodes

question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic for follow-up after receiving treatment for presumed pelvic inflammatory disease ten days ago. She initially presented with one week of pelvic pain and increased vaginal discharge. Initial examination revealed bilateral adnexal tenderness, cervical excitation and a moderate amount of thick, white vaginal discharge. She received the appropriate treatment and reports having completed the courses of antibiotics. She has no significant medical history, has an etonogestrel implant for contraception and has no plans for conceiving in the next few years. On examination today, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness or masses. Vaginal swab for microscopy, culture and sensitivity showed normal vaginal flora, and endocervical swabs for chlamydia, gonorrhoea and trichomoniasis were negative. A pelvic ultrasound was ordered as part of the initial work up and the results show a 37 x 24mm complex cystic structure on the left side that likely represents a hydrosalpinx. She completed treatment with the appropriate antibiotics. Which one of the following is the most appropriate management plan?
options: Reassurance and advise that she has completed treatment

question: A 38-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic with a three-month history of increasing pain in his left knee. The pain is now beginning to interfere with his job as a carpenter. He has no significant medical history but admits to a poor diet. He does not take any regular medications. On examination, he appears well. His pulse rate is 84/min, blood pressure 124/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 37.0°C. His BMI is 32 kg/m². The only abnormal finding on examination is some swelling and tenderness on pressure over the left patella, with no overlying erythema or break in skin integrity. There is a full range of movement of his knee. Which one of the following is the most appropriate management in addition to analgesia?

A 19-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a two-week history of a lump in her right breast. She has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Breast examination reveals a smooth, well-circumscribed lump in the right breast, approximately 3 cm in diameter. The lump is mobile. An ultrasound reveals a 3 cm mass with well-defined borders but a heterogeneous echotexture. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Referral for mammography to better characterise the lesion
Refer to Breast Screen for further assessment
Reassurance and encouragement of monthly breast checks
Referral for MRI to better characterise the lesion

question: A 30-year-old woman presents with acute onset of painful right eye movements in all directions. Her left eye is normal. This is her first episode. There is no history of trauma. She describes ‘blurry vision with ‘flickering’ in her peripheral visual field. She denies headache, neck pain, or speech disturbance. She has had weakness in both her legs, which was noticed two days ago after a hot shower. Her bladder and bowel continence are intact. A fundoscopic examination of the right eye demonstrates optic disc swelling. Which one of the following investigations is most appropriate?

A 30-year-old woman presents to her General Practice because she has been experiencing panic attacks over the last three months. During each episode, she feels her heart racing, her chest tightens, she feels faint and nauseated and has to sit down in a quiet room for it to stop. She is unable to pin point any identifiable triggers. She notices herself constantly ruminating about when the next one might happen, and the fear of experiencing subsequent panic attacks while out in public has held her back from going out as often as she would like to. The attacks are intermittent and unpredictable. She does not have a history of other mental illnesses, and does not have a history of recreational drug use, smoking or drinking alcohol. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a three-day history of worsening abdominal pain and distension, with some early mild confusion. He has a history of progressively worsening liver failure and has recently been referred to the palliative care service, as he is not a candidate for liver transplantation. In the past three weeks, he has had multiple presentations with decompensated liver disease, requiring recurrent drainage of ascitic fluid for comfort. He has a transient living situation and is currently homeless. He has no other significant medical history. His current medications include lactulose and spironolactone. On examination, he appears unwell and uncomfortable. His pulse rate is 88/min, blood pressure 110/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 20/min, SpO2 96% on room air, and temperature 36.7°C. His abdomen is grossly distended with a positive fluid thrill and shifting dullness. There is generalised tenderness on palpation but no guarding or rigidity. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 24-year-old final year University student attends her General Practice requesting medication to help with her “exam nerves”. She is able to function without issue throughout the day, sleeps seven hours a night, eats well, and exercises three times a week. She attends meditation classes and has tried “positive self-talking” but this has not prevented her anxieties. In practical exams, she says she “freezes”, gets a dry mouth, palpitations and “mind blank" and feels she will fail. She has previously failed a formative exam. Her upcoming examination is in 3 months' time. Which one of the following is most appropriate as first line treatment in this situation?

A 60-year-old woman presents to her General Practice clinic with a three-month history of bilateral wrist and knee pain associated with early morning stiffness. She also reports unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 kg and intermittent haemoptysis over the past month. She has a medical history of postpartum deep venous thrombosis treated with three months of anticoagulation. She takes no regular medications. She is an active smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history and drinks two glasses of wine per day. On examination, there is tenderness over both wrists and knees and she is noted to have convex nail beds. There is also nicotine staining of the right second and third digits. On auscultation of the chest, there is decreased air entry bilaterally and a widespread expiratory wheeze. Which one of the following is the most appropriate investigation to request next?
options: Rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies

question: An 86-year-old man presents to his General Practitioner after an episode of left sided abdominal pain the previous day, which resolved spontaneously after several hours. He has no other symptoms. His medical history includes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 10 years earlier and a colonoscopy for diverticulitis five years ago. He takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears well and vitals are all within normal limits. On abdominal examination the patient has a soft abdomen, with no masses. An abdominal CT scan is ordered. Which one of the following does the CT scan show?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a one-hour history of sudden clear fluid loss from her vagina while hanging washing. She is in her second pregnancy at 35 weeks’ gestation, with one previous birth. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She reports continued fetal movements and denies pain or contractions. She has no significant medical history and takes only pregnancy vitamins. On examination, she appears well. Her pulse rate is 80/min, blood pressure 110/80 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, SpO2 99% on room air, and temperature 36.8°C. The fetus is in a longitudinal lie with cephalic presentation, and the head is not engaged. There is no uterine tenderness. Speculum examination reveals no cord prolapse with clear fluid pooling in the posterior fornix with a closed cervix. Amnicator test is positive and microscopy shows ferning pattern. Group B Streptococcus swab has been collected. Cardiotocograph shows fetal heart rate 150/min with no decelerations or uterine contractions. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Preterm labour and associated placental abruption

question: A 28-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department following two weeks of progressive malaise, increasing abdominal distension and jaundice. He has no significant medical or surgical history and does not take any regular medications. He is a non-smoker and drinks two standard drinks of alcohol a week. He has a family history of antiphospholipid syndrome. On examination, he appears unwell with vital signs within normal limits. His clinical examination reveals an abnormality of the abdominal skin. His blood tests revealed abnormalities in liver function tests with bilirubin 60 mol/L (2-24), ALT 340 U/L (<55), AST 440 U/L (<45). An ultrasound abdomen revealed reversed flow in the hepatic veins. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this man's presentation?

A 22-year-old woman is admitted to the psychiatric ward with a diagnosis of anorexia nervosa. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 14 kg/m² and has been restricting her food intake severely for the past six months. A refeeding plan is initiated under close medical supervision. On day three of refeeding, she complains of muscle weakness and palpitations. On examination, she appears unwell. Her pulse rate is 110/min, blood pressure 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate 22/min, SpO2 97% on room air, and temperature 36.5°C. Heart sounds are normal, and chest is clear on auscultation. There is no peripheral oedema. Which one of the following is the most important investigation to perform at this stage?

A 72-year-old woman is referred by her General Practitioner to the Emergency Department due to concerns about systemic symptoms from a suspected urinary tract infection. She has a history of asthma and some intermittent indigestion but is otherwise well. As part of her septic workup, a chest X-ray is performed. Which one of the following findings is present in this chest X-ray?

A 65-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with acute onset of right-sided headache. The headache began 48 hours ago and is exacerbated by chewing food. Earlier this morning, she experienced transient bilateral vision loss while washing dishes. Her medical history includes polymyalgia rheumatica. She does not take any regular medications. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. On examination, she appears unwell. Her pulse rate is 82/min, blood pressure 145/85 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 38.3°C. She has since regained her vision with visual acuity of 6/6 in both eyes. Initial laboratory blood tests showed a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Intravenous methylprednisolone was initiated. A few days later, her symptoms have improved and vital signs are stable. A repeat blood test shows the following: Haemoglobin 100 g/L (115-155), White cell count 12.2 x 10⁹/L (4-11), Platelet count 268 x 10⁹/L (150-450), Absolute neutrophil count 13 x 10⁹/L (1.80-7.50), Absolute lymphocyte count 1.83 x 10⁹/L (1.10-3.50), Monocyte 0.35 x 10⁹/L (0.20-0.80), Eosinophil 0.06 x 10⁹/L (0.02-0.50), Basophil 0.03 x 10⁹/L (<0.10), C-reactive protein 10 mg/L (<5), ESR 22 mm/hr (1-20). Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory results?

A 22-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic with a four-week history of a mildly sore throat. He denies any rhinorrhoea, cough or fevers and has tried taking an antihistamine with no relief. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. He recalls attending his cousin's four-year old birthday party five weeks ago where many children had runny noses and coughing. His vaccinations are up to date. He has had four sexual partners in the last six months, all male, and engages in receptive anal intercourse and performs and receives oral sex. He uses condoms when having anal intercourse. On examination, he appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Oropharyngeal examination reveals mild erythema of the pharynx with mild tonsillar enlargement. There is no tonsillar exudate or cervical lymphadenopathy. A rapid strep test is negative. A throat swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). Which one of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?

A previously well 45-year-old man presents with a two month history of increasing fatigue which has become quite debilitating in the recent days. He has had episodes of itching over the last two weeks. He denies any joint or muscle pain. He does not smoke and drinks three glasses of wine at weekends. He is not on any medications. The physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory investigations show his haemoglobin, bilirubin, serum lipase and complete blood count all within normal limits but the serum alkaline phosphatase is elevated. Antimitochondrial antibody and rheumatoid factor are negative. Ultrasound shows evidence of abnormal bile ducts and an MR cholangiogram shows multifocal stricturing of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts. Apart from being treated for this condition he will be screened for any associated conditions for which he might be at risk. Which one of the following conditions should he be screened for next?

A 45-year-old woman presents with a six month history of progressively worsening dryness in her eyes. She describes a constant feeling of "sand" in her eyes. Along with that she also has mild discomfort and difficulty swallowing dry foods. She feels fatigued when climbing stairs, and often has knee pain with this. She also feels her hands are weaker and more tender generally, particularly when working at her desk. Occasionally, she has numbness in her hands. On examination, her conjunctiva appears dry. She has no rash. On examination of her joints, her knees have no effusions. She has no active synovitis of her wrists or metacarpophalangeal joints. Her radial, median and ulnar nerve function are intact bilaterally. Her Schirmer test is positive. Her antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive with a speckled pattern. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

A 60-year-old woman presents to the General Practice clinic with a six-month history of worsening and persistent right-sided hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness. She reports difficulty hearing out of her right ear, particularly when on the telephone, that is gradually worsening, with an associated sensation of fullness in the ear. She describes unsteadiness when walking and occasionally experiencing the room spinning around her. She has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, she appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Rinne's test is positive bilaterally, and Weber's test lateralises to the left. A change in head position does not elicit her symptoms. Cranial nerve examination reveals mild nystagmus; otherwise, all other cranial nerve functions are intact and normal. Otoscopic examination reveals minimal wax bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An eight-year-old boy presents to the General Practice clinic with a several-week history of right ear discharge. He reports having ear pain prior to the onset of discharge. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. On examination, he appears well. His pulse rate is 84/min and temperature 36.6°C. There are scars of a healing scabies infestation over the forearms. Otoscopic examination of the right ear reveals purulent discharge in the ear canal. Rinne’s test shows bone conduction greater than air conduction on the right. Weber's test lateralises to the right. Otoscopy reveals the following (Image). Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
options: Amoxicillin and clavulanic acid oral tablets

question: A 35-year-old woman attends her GP clinic with a few weeks history of general fatigue. She has a past medical history of obesity with a BMI of 31 kg/m, and she reports irregular menstrual cycles. Her father was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at age 50, but otherwise she has no family history of note. Her physical examination is normal. Her fasting blood glucose level is 6.2 mmol/L, and her HbAtc level is 6.0%. Other screening bloods for fatigue are unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next investigation?

A 56-year-old man presents with a two day history of recurrent headache. The headaches are one-sided, worse around the eye and occur in the form of attacks which last for 10-15 minutes. He has had about 10-20 attacks each day. They are associated with watery eyes and nose and are not triggered or exacerbated by anything. He had similar episodes of pain six months ago and they resolved spontaneously within two days. Since then he never had any episodes like the current one. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes, long-sightedness and a myocardial infarction two years ago. His blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, pulse 90/min and temperature 37.2°C. On ophthalmologic examination the anterior chamber angle is visible, the retina is unremarkable and there is a pinpoint pupil. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a three-day history of nausea, vomiting, and increasing drowsiness. He has no significant medical history and takes no regular medications. His partner reports that he does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, he appears unwell with a pulse rate of 120/min, blood pressure 105/60 mmHg, respiratory rate 22/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 37.8°C. He sleeps throughout the review and rouses with difficulty. He does not respond at all to voice and opens his eyes only briefly after painful stimuli, after which there is abnormal flexion of his limbs. He makes incomprehensible noises only, and does not follow any commands. His abdomen is soft with mild right upper quadrant tenderness. He is jaundiced, but otherwise has no stigmata of chronic liver disease. Investigations reveal: Bilirubin: 85 umol/L (5-21), ALT: 2500 U/L (7-56), AST: 2800 U/L (10-40), INR: 3.8 (0.8-1.2), Creatinine: 110 umol/L (45-90), Ammonia: 80 umol/L (11-32). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Transfer to a liver transplant centre

question: A 56-year-old woman undergoes an emergency right hemicolectomy for an obstructing carcinoma of the caecum. She has a BMI of 32 and a 30 pack-year smoking history. She does not take any medication. The surgery is uneventful and she makes a good post-operative recovery, apart from a chest infection. Six days after the operation a serosanguinous discharge is observed from the lower end of the wound. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman presents with a six-week history of a painless swelling in her left side of neck. She migrated from the Sudan three years ago. She has a forty-pack year smoking history and over the last few months has felt generally tired. She has developed anorexia and early satiety and lost 10 kg of weight. She has a chronic smoker's cough, but has not noticed any changes in this nor in her sputum. On examination there is a non-tender 2 cm smooth swelling deep to the skin in the left supraclavicular fossa. Examination of her chest and abdomen does not provide any helpful information other than signs of weight loss. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman presents to hospital in labour with strong regular contractions at 38 weeks gestation. She emigrated to Australia from Kenya three weeks ago and received little antenatal care throughout her pregnancy. She has no significant medical history and does not take any regular medications. She births her son vaginally three hours after presentation. On examination, the newborn appears well with a pulse rate of 140/min, respiratory rate 40/min, and temperature 36.8°C. Physical examination reveals the presence of a large anterior abdominal wall defect with viscera protruding through the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a thin membrane. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 30-minute history of shortness of breath and a sensation of her heart racing. She denies any chest pain or tightness and reports that this came on suddenly while having breakfast. She has never experienced an episode like this before. On further questioning, she reveals that she had a cup of coffee this morning as she was running late, while she usually consumes only tea. On examination, she is alert and orientated. Her heart rate is 140/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, SpO2 is 99%, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Examination of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 81-year-old man presents to a country emergency department with a three-day history of worsening difficulty passing urine, frequency, and lower abdominal discomfort. He reports a 7-year history of benign prostatic hyperplasia with lower urinary tract symptoms. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes, osteoarthritis, and previous deep vein thrombosis. His medications include metformin, perindopril, apixaban, and paracetamol. On examination, he appears mildly uncomfortable. His pulse rate is 82/min, blood pressure 128/81 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, SpO2 98% on room air, and temperature 36.7°C. His abdomen is soft with mild suprapubic tenderness. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged, smooth prostate. Post-void bladder scan shows a residual volume of 400 mL. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: Commence tamsulosin and arrange review in one week

question: A 77-year-old man presents to the General Practice clinic with a two-month history of progressive difficulty in speaking, with hoarseness and a change of tone in his voice. Over the same period, he has had difficulty with meals and notices an intermittent 'lump' sensation upon swallowing. His medical history includes nasal septum and inferior turbinate surgery six months ago, hip replacement, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His only medication is a statin for hyperlipidaemia. He quit smoking one year ago after a 50 pack-year history. He has limited exercise tolerance due to shortness of breath and hip pain. On examination, he appears well with vital signs within normal limits. Head and neck examination reveals no obvious masses or lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is most likely to establish a cause for his symptoms?

A 16-year-old boy presents to his General Practitioner as his parents are worried that he has not undergone the full extent of puberty. He states he does not have much pubic hair and thinks his penile size has not grown. He has also noticed that his sense of smell has become impaired. He has a medical history of undescended testicles in his early childhood which self-corrected. He takes no regular medications and his vaccinations are up to date. On physical examination, scant pubic hair and normally descended testes are shown. Blood investigations show plasma testosterone, luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormones are all low. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
